required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on April 10, 2017
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Increasing the Reach of Promising Dropout Prevention Programs: Examining the Trade-offs Between Scale and Effectiveness

collaborator.agency: Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL)

brief_summary.textblock: This research aims to examine the extent to which a promising academic intervention—high-intensity tutoring by SAGA Innovations—that has previously been shown to significantly improve academic outcomes for disadvantaged Chicago youth can be implemented at an even greater scale. By taking advantage of the power of random sampling, this study will allow for observation of the program's effectiveness as if it were running at five times the proposed scale. In addition, this study will explicitly explore the extent to which there is a trade-off between effectiveness and scale.

detailed_description.textblock:
The University of Chicago Education Lab research team is carrying out a randomized controlled trial during the 2016-2017 academic year to build on previous collaborations with the Chicago Public Schools (CPS) and SAGA Innovations that have found that SAGA's intensive, individualized, during-the-school-day tutoring can generate very large gains in academic outcomes in a short period of time, even among students who are many years behind grade level. This research suggests the promise of this approach for improving the academic skills and educational attainment of disadvantaged youth, even once they have reached adolescence, both in Chicago and in distressed urban districts across the country. However, to truly affect outcomes at the local and national level, SAGA would have to be rolled out on a much greater scale than researchers have been able to study in Chicago. Yet little is known about how to take promising interventions to scale. This study seeks to build the science of scale-up, by examining the extent to which this individualized tutoring program can be implemented at an even greater scale and by explicitly exploring the trade-offs between effectiveness and scale.
The SAGA Innovations program expands on the nationally recognized innovation of high-dosage, in-school-day tutoring developed in Match Education's charter school in Boston. The tutoring program meets as a scheduled course, Math Lab, once a day during the normal school day, and is provided in addition to a student's regular math class. Students taking the course receive an elective credit upon completion. Students work two-on-one (two students with one tutor) with the same full-time, professional tutor for the entirety of the school year. The content of the tutoring sessions is aligned with what students are learning in their regular math courses, but is also targeted to address individual gaps in math knowledge. Also following the original model developed by Match Education, SAGA tutors use frequent internal formative assessments of student progress to individualize instruction.
A previous randomized controlled trial conducted by the University of Chicago research team found that one year of this intervention, delivered in AY2013-14, generated between one and two extra years of academic growth in math, over and above what the normal U.S. high school student learns in one year (Cook et al., 2015; Reardon 2011). The estimated effects for math achievement are on the order of 0.19 to 0.30 SD, depending on the exact test and norming used. This effect is equivalent to closing up to one-third of the black-white test score gap in math in the NAEP among thirteen-year-olds (0.80 SD), in just one year. The intervention also improved student grades in math by 0.58 points on a 1-4 grade point scale, compared to a control mean of 1.77. These gains are particularly important because of the growing evidence on the importance of math specifically for short- and medium-term success in school, and for long-term life outcomes such as employment and earnings (Duncan et al., 2007).
This study aims to build upon the investigators' previous evaluations of the program, and will provide insight into the ability of this program to serve youth at a much larger scale. The investigators will take advantage of the power of random sampling to study scale-up of this program without actually having to implement the program at a much larger scale. For example, in 2016-17 academic year, SAGA will be serving about 1,200 kids in the Chicago Public Schools, and so will need to hire about 100 tutors. Researchers believe they can simulate the range of tutors SAGA would need to hire if it were being delivered on a much larger scale in Chicago—say, to 3,000 students. To serve 3,000 students, SAGA would have to hire 250 tutors. To hire 250 tutors, SAGA would typically recruit a pool of 2,000 applicants, of which about 1,000 would be deemed qualified enough to be interviewed. To simulate this hiring process and the tutors SAGA would hire if they were serving 3,000 students, researchers will have SAGA recruit a target of 1,000 interview-able applicants, and will randomly select one in five for them to actually interview. SAGA will then offer the position to their top 50 candidates from this pool of 200 interviews. Simulations suggest that this approach will provide an unbiased estimate of the 250 tutors that would have been hired had the program been implemented at five times the proposed scale. SAGA staff will also rank these 50 tutors (hereby referred to as "scale-up tutors") based on expected success in improving academic outcomes of students, to enable the researchers to examine the extent to which tutor ranking moderates program effects. SAGA will be responsible for the recruitment of tutors, and will use their standard recruitment methods (career fairs, job postings, online advertisements, etc.) to reach the anticipated 1,000 interview-able applicants. SAGA will also select another set of 50 tutors via their standard hiring process (hereby referred to as "standard tutors"), which does not involve randomization. These 50 standard tutors will allow the investigators to compare the effectiveness of SAGA tutoring when implemented on a small versus large scale.
The schools in this study will also be divided into two sets, based on whether SAGA tutoring has been implemented there in the past. In about half of the schools, where SAGA-style tutoring has been implemented since AY2013-14 or AY2014-15, researchers will allow schools to choose which students they believe should participate in tutoring. In the second half of schools, which have never implemented SAGA-style tutoring, investigators will administer the program as a randomized controlled trial, by identifying youth who are at elevated risk for failing academically and randomly assigning them to one of two conditions—SAGA tutoring, or a control group receiving status quo school and community services. In both sets of schools, the students assigned to tutoring will be randomly assigned to a particular tutor in their school. For the scale-up tutors, this random assignment of students to tutors coupled with the randomization of tutor selection will allow researchers to examine the impact of individualized tutoring as if 250 tutors were hired, and will enable researchers to empirically estimate the supply curve for implementing this individualized tutoring program at much larger scale. For the standard tutors, the random assignment of students to tutors will allow researchers to examine the effect of implementing the individualized tutoring on a small scale, if just 50 tutors were hired.
At the end of AY2016-17, researchers will examine the impact of this program on important academic and behavioral outcomes. This includes outcomes such as GPA, credits attempted, credits earned, standardized test scores, and crime involvement. Researchers will also have access SAGA's programmatic data on tutor characteristics, which includes demographic information and information on math and teacher training, to assess the variation in the effectiveness of tutors and to examine the degree to which tutor characteristics correspond to different student outcomes.
Researchers believe the proposed project will provide valuable insights into how to scale up what may turn out to be an extremely cost-effective way to improve educational outcomes for low-income youth. But perhaps more importantly, the hope is that this work will contribute to a broader understanding of how program scale affects program quality and how to systematically study this relationship. The investigators hope this project will create a "roadmap" for a growing body of research on the science of scale-up, guiding efforts of future researchers to understand the implications of scale up for interventions with scarce inputs.

primary_outcome.description: Performance on math standardized achievement tests

secondary_outcome.description: Math course grades, obtained from Chicago Public Schools administrative database
Number of school absences, obtained from Chicago Public Schools (CPS) administrative database

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in index of CPS schooling outcomes
secondary_outcome.description: Index of standardized (in Z-score form) outcomes for school persistence, absences, and course grades
Number of school misconduct infractions, obtained from Chicago Public Schools administrative database
Number of total school courses failed, obtained from Chicago Public Schools administrative database
Number of math courses failed, obtained from Chicago Public Schools administrative database
Number of non-math courses failed, obtained from Chicago Public Schools administrative database
Measure from CPS student records of school persistence (enrollment or graduation status by end of academic year)
Number of violent crime arrests, obtained from Chicago Police Department and Illinois State Police administrative databases

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in other arrests (property, drug, and other crimes)
secondary_outcome.description: Number of non-violent crime arrests, including property crimes, drug crimes, and other crimes, obtained from Chicago Police Department and Illinois State Police administrative databases
Quarterly earnings collected by the Illinois Department of Employment Security, maintained for the state unemployment insurance system

arm_group.description: These youth will receive standard mathematics instruction and support (including possibly other tutoring interventions), but not the daily, intensive, during-the-school-day math tutoring provided by SAGA.

These youth will receive intensive, daily mathematics tutoring, and students will be paired with scale-up tutors. Tutors will be hired using the randomization process, and will be randomly assigned to youth.

These youth will receive intensive, daily mathematics tutoring, and students will be paired with tutors hired via SAGA's standard process, which does not involve randomization. Tutors will be randomly assigned to youth.

intervention.description: Tutors who have been selected for hire via the one-in-five randomization process
Tutors who have been selected for hire via SAGA's standard hiring process, which does not entail randomization

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Low-performing Chicago Public School high schools, chosen in collaboration with the Chicago Public Schools based on criteria such as dropout rate, test scores, scores on academic rating scale, etc.
- School administrators are enthusiastic about the program and agree to terms and conditions of the experimental design
- Male and female youth within these schools who are rising 9th and 10th graders in academic year (AY) 2016-17
- Applicants who apply to be a tutor for SAGA Innovations
Exclusion Criteria:
- Youth who have missed >60% of days during AY2015-16 (through March), and so would not be expected to show up in school enough during intervention year (AY2016-17) to benefit from school-based programming
- Youth who have failed >75% of classes during AY2015-16 (through March)
- Youth who have Individualized Education Program (IEP) designations for autism, "educable mentally handicapped," and/or traumatic brain injury

reference.citation: Cook P, Dodge K, Farkas G, Fryer RG, Guryan J, Ludwig J, Mayer S, Pollack H, Steinberg L. Not Too Late: Improving Academic Outcomes for Disadvantaged Youth. Northwestern Institute for Policy Research Working Paper, February 2015.

Cook P, Dodge K, Farkas G, Fryer RG, Guryan J, Ludwig J, Mayer S, Pollack H, Steinberg L. The (Surprising) Efficacy of Academic and Behavioral Intervention with Disadvantaged Youth: Results from a Randomized Experiment in Chicago. Cambridge, MA: National Bureau of Economic Research, Working Paper No. 19862, 2014.
Fryer RG. Injecting Charter School Best Practices into Traditional Public Schools: Evidence from Field Experiments. The Quarterly Journal of Economics 129(3): 1355-1407, 2014.
